g:descriptionGroup.p:description: Data is protected from unauthorized use and disclosure. Information is protected in accordance with local and International law, regulations, and enterprise-wide rules.

a:principleArtifact.p:rationale: The demands of information sharing must be balanced with the need to protect classified, proprietary, and sensitive information. There is a vast amount of information that has to be shared inside in the enterprise. There is information that must be made publicly available; all this information must be protected using existing local and International laws, regulations requiring the safeguarding of information related to national security, and privacy of data, while still permitting free and open access to various kinds of information. All data restricted by laws and regulations, as well as pre-decisional information (information that is non-disclosure, work documents, internal enterprise material, information related to enterprise intellectual property etc.) must be protected to avoid violation of the law, leakage of enterprise intellectual property, unwarranted speculation, misinterpretation, and any inappropriate use.
a:principleArtifact.p:implications: Data and information handled within the enterprise must be classified according to its sensitiveness. The classification must be regularly checked for timeliness and accuracy, as the law, regulation requirements and enterprise needs may change over time. There must be also procedures, policies and mechanisms enabling regular review and re-classification of the data and information. The information classification must drive the security and data protection mechanisms in applications, technical infrastructure, supporting processes, access rules, data usage principles etc. across their entire life cycle - from design, through development, deployment and use, up to retirement. In order to adequately provide access to information while maintaining a required level of its security, the data/information protection needs must be identified and developed at the data level, not at the application or system level. Sensitivity labeling for access to pre-decisional, decisional, classified, sensitive, or proprietary information must be determined. Security must be designed into data elements from the beginning; it cannot be added later. Systems, data, and technologies must be protected from unauthorized access and manipulation. Managerial information must be safeguarded against inadvertent or unauthorized alteration, sabotage, disaster, or disclosure. If not in place yet, the Information Security Governance framework needs to be developed and implemented to enable and drive an effective securing of information in the enterprise.
